msDesc.head:
Letter from
Frances Edgeworth
to Esther Brinkley, Dunsink Observatory, 8 August 1818

div.p:
When I consider that so many
days have elapsed since the return of
William and Harriet without my having
written a single line to you - I feel
quite ashamed of my seeming ingrati=
=tude ingratitude for the innumerable and essential
kindnesses that he received from everyone
at the Observatory but chiefly from you
his second mother as he calls you. The
fact is that I felt so overwhelmed with
the account his sister and himself gave
me of the infinite trouble he occasioned to
your whole family and the infinite goodness
wh with which it was borne and with which

not only the real wants but the caprices of an
invalid were attended to - that I could not find
words to express such thanks as would convey
my feelings and be acceptable to your generous
mind. We all thank you and the Doctor &
Mr Mat Brinkly Brinkley
- and your gentle amiable
daughter if not with our lips, with our hearts
every hour of the day - and also that good
excellent Catherine for whom William has
made feel respect and admiration.

Since William's return he has been very
variable, during these days that we spent
at Admiral Pakenhams he was wonderful
-ly wonderfully well. Since that he has had a consider
-able considerable return of pain - and consequent feeble
-ness feebleness and last night felt the crackling
noise in his head that he noticed while
at the observatory - He is better today - no, I should

say he is better just at this moment - for it
requires both morning and evening to complete
a day. Let me not thank you and the Doctor
for your kindness to him alone but for your
his
great goodness to my daughter - She
idolizes Dr B. and the seeds he has thrown
into her mind have not fallen into a barren
or ungrateful soil.

Maria and Honora left us last week
for the County of Meath on their way
to
Dubl Dublin
and their grand expedition - Which
I trust will turn out as happily as it seems
well planned. I fear their passage through
Dublin will be so short that they cannot
make their way to you - but they will be
to be heard of at 31 Merrion Street.
div.closer:
Adieu my dear rs Brinkley with most
affectionate remembrances to the Dr & Miss B.
Believe me very sincerely your Obliged
and attached
F. Edgeworth
